unit_title: Radioactive Decay: Alpha, Beta, Gamma Decay Processes
subject: AP Physics 2
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of radioactive decay processes including alpha, beta, and gamma decay, their mechanisms, energy considerations, decay laws, and applications in science and technology.
learning_objectives: Describe the three main types of radioactive decay and their mechanisms
Write balanced nuclear equations for decay processes
Calculate decay energies and kinetic energy distributions
Explain the quantum tunneling mechanism in alpha decay
Describe the role of neutrinos in beta decay
Solve problems involving half-life and decay constants
Apply decay principles to real-world applications

core_concept.principle: Radioactive Decay, Alpha Decay, Beta Decay, Gamma Decay, Half-Life, Decay Constant, Quantum Tunneling, Neutrino Physics
core_concept.explanation: Radioactive decay occurs when unstable nuclei spontaneously transform into more stable configurations through alpha, beta, or gamma emission, following exponential decay laws governed by quantum mechanical probabilities.

image.caption: Alpha, beta, and gamma decay processes and characteristics

sections.introduction: Examining alpha decay as a quantum tunneling process where heavy nuclei emit alpha particles to achieve greater stability, and analyzing the energy considerations and barrier penetration mechanisms.

key_concept.definition: Alpha decay, Alpha particle, Quantum tunneling, Coulomb barrier, Gamow factor, Decay energy, Geiger-Nuttall law, Barrier penetration
key_concept.context: Alpha decay involves the emission of helium-4 nuclei from heavy unstable nuclei through quantum mechanical tunneling through the Coulomb barrier, with decay rates following systematic patterns described by the Geiger-Nuttall law.

image.caption: Alpha decay mechanism and quantum tunneling

classifications.value: Classification based on alpha decay properties and mechanisms
characteristics: Coulomb barrier height (~20-30 MeV for heavy nuclei)
Decay constant range (10¹⁸ s⁻¹ to 10⁻¹⁸ s⁻¹)
classifications.behavior: Alpha decay exhibits characteristic behaviors including monoenergetic alpha particle emission, extremely wide range of half-lives from nanoseconds to billions of years, systematic energy-half-life relationships, daughter nucleus recoil, and occasional fine structure with multiple discrete alpha energies from the same parent nucleus

classifications.note: Alpha particle: ⁴He nucleus (2p+2n); Energy: typically 4-9 MeV; Range: very short in matter (cm in air); Applications: smoke detectors, nuclear batteries, radiotherapy

principles.statement: Alpha decay proceeds through quantum mechanical barrier penetration: Alpha Particle: ⁴He nucleus (2 protons, 2 neutrons); Very stable configuration; Often pre-formed in nucleus. Decay Process: ᴬZX → ᴬ⁻⁴Z⁻₂Y + ⁴₂He + Q; Q-value = kinetic energy released; Shared between alpha and daughter. Coulomb Barrier: Electrostatic repulsion between alpha and daughter; Height ~20-30 MeV for heavy nuclei; Much higher than typical alpha energies (4-9 MeV). Quantum Tunneling: Wavefunction penetrates classically forbidden region; Probability ∝ exp(-2G) where G is Gamow factor; Explains wide range of half-lives. Gamow Factor: G = (2πZ₁Z₂e²)/(ħv) × (arccos√(E/V) - √(E/V(1-E/V))); Determines tunneling probability; Very sensitive to energy E. Geiger-Nuttall Law: logλ = a - b/√E; Relates decay constant λ to alpha energy E; Systematic trend across heavy elements. Energy Considerations: Q-value = [m_parent - (m_daughter + m_alpha)]c²; Kinetic energy: E_alpha ≈ (A-4)/A × Q (due to recoil); Discrete energies due to quantum states. Fine Structure: Multiple alpha groups from same parent; Different excited states of daughter nucleus; Different energies and intensities. Historical Development: Rutherford (1899) discovery; Gamow (1928) quantum explanation; Modern: sophisticated potential models.
principles.application: Write alpha decay equations. Calculate Q-values and kinetic energies. Estimate half-lives from alpha energies. Solve tunneling probability problems. Analyze decay chains. Apply conservation laws to decay processes.
principles.example: Write uranium-238 alpha decay equation. Calculate alpha particle energy from Q-value. Estimate half-life using Geiger-Nuttall relationship. Analyze fine structure in alpha spectra.
principles.analogy: Like rolling a ball up a hill that's too high to go over classically, but the ball occasionally 'tunnels' through the hill - the alpha particle is trapped in a 'valley' (nuclear potential) behind a tall 'hill' (Coulomb barrier), and even though it doesn't have enough energy to go over the hill, there's a small probability it can appear on the other side, with this probability being extremely sensitive to how close the ball gets to the top of the hill (alpha energy) and the hill's steepness (nuclear charge)

image.caption: Principles of alpha decay and quantum tunneling

worked_examples.title: Alpha Decay Energy Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the Q-value and kinetic energies for the alpha decay of ²³⁸U to ²³⁴Th. Given: m(²³⁸U)=238.050788 u, m(²³⁴Th)=234.043601 u, m(⁴He)=4.002603 u.

step_by_step.explanation: Experimental: 4.27 MeV total, 4.20 MeV alpha - excellent agreement

worked_examples.final_answer: Q-value = 4.27 MeV; Alpha particle energy = 4.20 MeV; Thorium recoil energy = 0.072 MeV; Most energy goes to alpha particle due to lighter mass

worked_examples.title: Geiger-Nuttall Law Application
worked_examples.problem: Using the Geiger-Nuttall law, estimate how the half-life changes when alpha energy increases from 4 MeV to 8 MeV. Assume typical parameters where logλ = 50 - 140/√E.

step_by_step.explanation: Doubling alpha energy changes half-life by ~20 orders of magnitude!

worked_examples.final_answer: Increasing alpha energy from 4 MeV to 8 MeV decreases half-life from ~2 trillion years to ~0.2 seconds - a change of 20 orders of magnitude! Demonstrates extreme sensitivity of alpha decay rates to energy.

sections.introduction: Exploring beta decay as a process governed by the weak nuclear force, involving the transformation of nucleons and the essential role of neutrinos in energy and momentum conservation.

key_concept.definition: Beta decay, Weak nuclear force, Neutrino, Electron, Positron, Electron capture, Fermi theory, Beta spectrum, Continuous energy distribution
key_concept.context: Beta decay involves the transformation of neutrons into protons or vice versa through the weak nuclear force, with continuous energy spectra requiring the hypothesis of neutrinos to conserve energy, momentum, and angular momentum.

image.caption: Beta decay processes and neutrino physics

classifications.value: Classification based on the specific weak interaction process
characteristics: Double beta decay (two simultaneous beta decays)
Inverse beta decay (ν + n → p + e⁻)
classifications.behavior: Different beta decay variants involve specific transformations between nucleons mediated by W bosons, with beta-minus decay increasing atomic number, beta-plus decay decreasing atomic number, electron capture also decreasing atomic number but without positron emission, and each process having characteristic energy requirements and selection rules

examples.explanation: Neutron transformation to proton with electron and antineutrino emission

image.caption: Beta-minus decay mechanism and energy spectrum

examples.explanation: Continuous energy distribution of beta particles

image.caption: Continuous beta energy spectrum and endpoint energy

classifications.note: Beta particles: electrons or positrons; Energy: continuous spectrum up to endpoint; Neutrinos: essential for conservation laws; Applications: nuclear medicine, dating methods, neutrino physics

principles.statement: Beta decay involves weak force transformations with neutrino emission: Beta-Minus Decay: n → p + e⁻ + ν̄; Occurs in neutron-rich nuclei; Increases Z by 1; Example: ¹⁴₆C → ¹⁴₇N + e⁻ + ν̄. Beta-Plus Decay: p → n + e⁺ + ν; Occurs in proton-rich nuclei; Requires Q > 2m_ec² (1.022 MeV); Decreases Z by 1. Electron Capture: p + e⁻ → n + ν; Alternative to β⁺ decay; No positron emission requirement; Characteristic X-rays emitted. Energy Considerations: Q-value = [m_parent - m_daughter]c²; For β⁺: Q > 2m_ec² required; Continuous energy spectrum up to E_max = Q. Neutrino Hypothesis: Pauli (1930) proposed neutrino; Explains continuous beta spectrum; Carries missing energy and momentum; Fermi (1934) theory. Beta Spectrum: Continuous distribution; Shape depends on nuclear matrix elements; Kurie plot linear for allowed transitions; Endpoint energy = Q-value. Selection Rules: Fermi transitions: ΔJ=0, no parity change; Gamow-Teller transitions: ΔJ=0,±1 (not 0→0), parity change; Most decays mixed. Weak Interaction: Mediated by W± bosons; Coupling constant G_F = 1.166×10⁻⁵ GeV⁻²; Very weak compared to electromagnetic. Historical Puzzles: Continuous spectrum seemed to violate energy conservation; Missing spin/statistics; All resolved by neutrino.
principles.application: Write beta decay equations. Calculate Q-values and endpoint energies. Analyze beta spectra. Determine decay mode feasibility. Solve neutrino energy problems. Apply selection rules to transitions.
principles.example: Write carbon-14 beta decay equation. Calculate maximum beta energy. Determine if positron decay is possible. Analyze Kurie plot data.
principles.analogy: Like a three-way financial transaction where the total amount of money is fixed (energy conservation) but can be split differently between three people - the electron, the neutrino, and the recoiling nucleus - with the neutrino being the 'silent partner' who can carry away any amount of money needed to balance the books, explaining why we see different amounts going to the electron in different transactions while the total always adds up correctly

image.caption: Principles of beta decay and neutrino physics

worked_examples.title: Beta Decay Energy Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Calculate the Q-value and maximum beta energy for the decay of ¹⁴C to ¹⁴N. Given: m(¹⁴C)=14.003242 u, m(¹⁴N)=14.003074 u.

step_by_step.explanation: E_max = Q = 0.156 MeV (when neutrino gets zero energy)
Low energy makes ¹⁴C useful for dating organic materials

worked_examples.final_answer: Q-value = 0.156 MeV; Maximum beta energy = 0.156 MeV; This low energy makes carbon-14 dating possible and explains its long half-life (5730 years)

worked_examples.title: Positron Decay Feasibility
worked_examples.problem: Determine if sodium-22 can decay by positron emission. Given: m(²²Na)=21.994437 u, m(²²Ne)=21.991385 u.

step_by_step.explanation: Q > 0, so positron decay is possible
Electron capture also possible and competes with positron decay
²²Na actually decays by both β⁺ (90%) and EC (10%)

worked_examples.final_answer: Positron decay is possible with Q = 1.821 MeV; Sodium-22 decays by both positron emission and electron capture, with positron endpoint energy 0.545 MeV (shared with neutrino)

sections.introduction: Examining gamma decay as electromagnetic transitions between nuclear energy states, and analyzing the mathematical laws governing radioactive decay including half-life, activity, and decay series.

key_concept.definition: Gamma decay, Nuclear isomers, Half-life, Decay constant, Activity, Decay series, Secular equilibrium, Exponential decay
key_concept.context: Gamma decay involves the emission of high-energy photons from excited nuclear states, while radioactive decay follows exponential laws characterized by half-lives and decay constants that are fundamental properties of each radionuclide.

image.caption: Gamma decay and radioactive decay laws

classifications.value: Classification based on multipolarity and selection rules
classifications.behavior: Different gamma transition types follow specific selection rules based on angular momentum and parity changes, with transition probabilities decreasing rapidly with increasing multipole order, electric transitions typically being faster than magnetic transitions of the same multipolarity, and internal conversion competing with gamma emission especially for low-energy transitions in heavy elements

examples.explanation: Discrete nuclear states and gamma transitions between them

image.caption: Nuclear energy levels and gamma decay transitions

examples.explanation: Mathematical description of radioactive decay over time

image.caption: Exponential decay law and half-life concept

classifications.note: Gamma rays: high-energy photons; Energy: discrete nuclear transitions; Half-life: time for half the nuclei to decay; Activity: decays per second; Applications: medical imaging, cancer therapy, industrial radiography

principles.statement: Gamma decay and radioactive decay follow specific physical and mathematical principles: Gamma Decay: Emission of high-energy photons; Nuclear transitions between excited states; Energy E_γ = E_initial - E_final; Discrete energies characteristic of nucleus. Multipole Radiation: Classified by angular momentum change Δl; Electric (E1, E2, E3...) and magnetic (M1, M2, M3...); Transition rates decrease with multipole order; Selection rules: |J_i - J_f| ≤ l ≤ J_i + J_f. Internal Conversion: Alternative to gamma emission; Nuclear energy transferred directly to atomic electron; Creates conversion electron; Important for low-energy transitions. Nuclear Isomers: Long-lived excited states; Metastable due to large spin differences; Examples: ⁹⁹ᵐTc (6 hours), ¹⁸⁰ᵐTa (>10¹⁵ years). Exponential Decay Law: N(t) = N₀e^(-λt); λ = decay constant; Characteristic for each nuclide; Statistical process. Half-Life: T₁/₂ = ln2/λ = 0.693/λ; Time for half the nuclei to decay; Range: 10⁻²² s to 10²⁴ years. Activity: A(t) = λN(t) = A₀e^(-λt); Units: becquerel (Bq) = 1 decay/s; curie (Ci) = 3.7×10¹⁰ Bq. Decay Series: Chains of sequential decays; Natural series: uranium, thorium, actinium; Secular equilibrium: activity equality in series. Measurement Techniques: Geiger counters, scintillation detectors, semiconductor detectors; Spectroscopy for energy analysis.
principles.application: Write gamma decay equations. Calculate half-lives and decay constants. Solve exponential decay problems. Determine activity from mass and half-life. Analyze decay chains. Apply decay laws to dating methods.
principles.example: Calculate remaining activity after given time. Determine half-life from decay data. Analyze gamma energy transitions. Solve secular equilibrium problems.
principles.analogy: Like a crowd of people leaving a stadium at different rates - each person has their own characteristic exit time (decay constant), the number of people remaining follows an exponential curve, the 'half-time' is when half the crowd has left (half-life), and the exit rate at any moment (activity) is proportional to how many people remain, with some people taking special exits (gamma decay from excited states) while others leave through main exits (alpha/beta decay)

image.caption: Principles of gamma decay and radioactive decay laws

worked_examples.title: Exponential Decay Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A sample contains 1.0 μg of ¹⁴C (T₁/₂=5730 years). Calculate the initial activity and the activity after 10,000 years.

step_by_step.explanation: After 10,000 years, activity drops to ~30% of initial, measurable for dating

worked_examples.final_answer: Initial activity = 1.65×10⁵ Bq (4.46 μCi); Activity after 10,000 years = 4.92×10⁴ Bq; Demonstrates principle of radiocarbon dating

worked_examples.title: Decay Chain Analysis
worked_examples.problem: In the uranium decay series, ²³⁸U (T₁/₂=4.5×10⁹ y) decays to ²³⁴Th (T₁/₂=24.1 d). Calculate the time needed for ²³⁴Th to reach secular equilibrium with its parent.

step_by_step.explanation: Daughter activity equals parent activity when daughter half-life << parent half-life
A_daughter/A_parent = 1 - e^(-λ_daughter t) ≈ 1 when t >> T₁/₂_daughter
After ~5 months, thorium activity essentially equals uranium activity
In uranium ores, ²³⁴Th reaches equilibrium quickly compared to geological timescales

worked_examples.final_answer: ²³⁴Th reaches 99% of secular equilibrium after 161 days (about 5 months); Much shorter than parent half-life, so equilibrium is maintained in natural uranium samples

image.caption: Decay chain and secular equilibrium analysis

common_misconceptions: Thinking all radiation is man-made or dangerous
Believing radioactive decay can be sped up or slowed down
Thinking beta particles have discrete energies
Believing gamma rays are particles like alpha and beta
Assuming half-life means all atoms decay in that time
Thinking radiation always makes things radioactive
Believing radioactive decay violates conservation laws
summary: Radioactive decay encompasses three fundamental processes: alpha decay involving quantum tunneling of helium nuclei through Coulomb barriers, beta decay mediated by the weak force with continuous energy spectra requiring neutrinos, and gamma decay consisting of electromagnetic transitions between nuclear energy states. These processes follow exponential decay laws characterized by half-lives ranging from fractions of seconds to billions of years. Alpha decay exhibits discrete energies and follows the Geiger-Nuttall law relating energy to half-life, beta decay involves transformations between nucleons with three variants (beta-minus, beta-plus, electron capture), and gamma decay follows multipole selection rules with possible competition from internal conversion. The mathematical description of radioactive decay enables applications from radiometric dating to nuclear medicine, while the physical mechanisms provide insights into fundamental forces and quantum phenomena. Understanding these decay processes is essential for both practical applications in medicine and energy and for fundamental research in nuclear and particle physics.
